div1.p: Peabody writes about circulating the “Yellow Fever Story of Heroism“ to high schools and colleges.

div1.head: Letter from James E. Peabody to Howard A. Kelly, April 2, 1927

opener.dateline:
The Morris High School
166TH ST. AND BOSTON ROAD
NEW YORK CITY
_____o_____
THE MORRIS SERVICE LEAGUE
JAMES E. PEABODY
CHAIRMAN THE TEACHER'S COMMITTEE
April 2, 1927.

div1.p:
Perhaps you may think there has been a rather long period
of silence since I wrote you last. The truth is that the Kis-
singer Campaign and my other work did me up, and for three
months (December to February) I had all I could do to force
myself through the motions of teaching school. I am in fine
shape now, and I am trying my best to let “George” do most of
this extra work that has come my way since Dr. Fosdick preached
that wonderful sermon five weeks ago. I enclose some material
that will give you some idea of the progress we have made. We
now have in hand about $1300, certainly enough for any immediate
needs of the Kissingers. We hope to get the little place for
them in season for them to plant their garden.

I had to send you, during my illness, Mrs. Kissinger's appeal
for help for her hospital expenses, and I received your kind
answer. Enclosed is her latest answer to my questions, and my
reply to her. I do not wish to seem to impose on you, but I
know the interest you have already shown in the Kissingers, and
we are all eager to have them enjoy a few years at least free
from suffering and anxiety, if such a thing is possible. You
see I have made bold to ask her to write you, even though you
should find it impossible to give any advice at long range. If
the doctors there only agreed, we could leave it to them. Any
advice you can give will be most gratefully received by all of
us.

We have rather a remarkable Citizens' Committee, don't you
think. We had a meeting of our Biology Association Committee
yesterday, and decided to memorialize every College and High
School Biology Department we can reach in this Country, to the
end that The Yellow Fever Story of Heroism may be taught widely
before the end of this school year. In the Autumn we propose
to storm Congress and to secure gold medals for all the survi-
vors of those gruesome experiments or for their widows. We
are sure we can count on you and Dr. Welch for ardent support.
Will you please answer by special delivery, addressed to the
school, giving us your advice relative to Mrs. Kissinger and our
campaign.

Please give my regards to your good wife and to the sons and
daughters I met. Our good friends the Tracy's enjoyed so much
your Lenten Talks in Washington.
